awd_abstract_narration: This award funds three conferences that will stimulate new research in the interdisciplinary area of cliometrics, which combines economics, statistics, history, demography, sociology, anthropology, anatomy, and climatology as well as other disciplines to examine core questions about economic theory and the development of modern economies. The conferences bring together young scholars, including graduate students, with a group of excellent senior scholars to engage in workshop sessions that give intensive commentary on early research results. The goal is to improve research quality, promote graduate training, and allow young scholars to build deeper research networks. The result is better scientific knowledge about the evolution and structural dynamics of the U.S. economy and the international economy. The conferences advance science, promote the training of U.S. students in this area, and shed valuable light on how government and business decisions can affect the U.S. economic competitiveness.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the project was to organize conferences of cliometricians to present their research, interact, and form networks in a supportive environment.  Scholars of all ranks are invited, but there is an emphasis on graduate students and scholars early in their careers.  At the 2018 Conference, 'Egg-timer' sessions were introduced to give additional graduate students a chance to share their research.  These are 10 minute per speaker presentations.  No questions are asked during the sessions, but the sessions precede breaks, where further engagement is encouraged.  The program committee makes an effort to include, both as presenters and attendees, academics from all types of institutions, including those which are less research focused.  Thus, these conferences contribute to the professional development of faculty, and thus the teaching of economics, at a wide range of institutions.  The project helped to fund annual conferences in 2018, 2019, 2021, and 2022 and a world congress of cliometrics in 2023 also.  The project also supported the planning of the 2020 conference which had to be cancelled due to the Covid pandemic.

'Cliometrics' is economics in the service of history and history in the service of economics.  Cliometricians apply economic theory and quantitative analysis to a wide range of economic and historical issues. At the simplest level, this consists of making observations of economic behavior and measuring variables relevant to the articulation of or the testing of an economic theory or model. Human experience, however, is complex, and cliometricians also seek to examine the forces underlying the development of institutions and government, in order to understand the long-term patterns of development throughout the world.

Cliometric conferences follow a format which has been found to promote intellectual discussion and debate.  Each paper receives its own 60-minute session at a conference and 45-minute session at a world congress.  Conference Program Committees chose 11 papers for presentation at each of the annual conferences and 88 papers for presentation at the 2023 world congress. Each author(s) was limited to a maximum of 5 minutes with no formal discussants assigned. The remainder of the session was spent in questions and answers from the floor. Each conference participant received an electronic pdf containing the conference book consisting of information about the conference, research summaries for each participant, and the papers to be discussed at the conference. The attendees accepted to read the paper in advance for each of the sessions.  At an annual conference, all sessions were attended by all Conference participants.  Having the limited author presentation and with all attendees having read the paper fosters an often spirited discussion of the paper among participants. This structure stimulates a workshop atmosphere that encourages participants to speak freely and to build new professional relationships. There was also an attempt to balance the attendees to provide the best possible feedback on the papers presented.  Conversations and discussions extend through the break times.  The spirit is tough but respectful and lively, and the conference organizers worked to perpetuate this atmosphere by having a balance of seasoned cliometricians and participants new to the field from a wide range of schools and countries. 

The 2018 Annual Cliometric Conference was hosted by Florida State University, April 27 and 28, 2018 in Tallahassee, Florida. There were 46 invited participants from the United States, Canada, and Europe.  The participants included 14 women and 14 graduate students.

The 2019 Annual Cliometric Conference was hosted by the Ohio State University, May 31 and June 1, 2019 in Columbus, Ohio. There were 44 invited participants from the United States, Canada, and Europe.  The participants included 11 women and 14 graduate students.

The 2020 Annual Cliometric Conference was planned to be hosted by Chapman University in Orange, California.  Unfortunately, it was cancelled in April of that year due to the Covid pandemic.

The 2021 Annual Cliometric Conference was held online, and was jointly hosted by Chapman University and Binghamton University, June 24-26, 2021. There were 40 invited participants from the United States, Canada, Europe and Asia.  The participants included 18 women and 15 graduate students.

The 2022 Annual Cliometric Conference was hosted by Vanderbilt University, May 20 to 21, 2022 in Nashville, Tennessee. There were 44 invited participants from the United States, Canada, and Europe.  The participants included 14 women and 17 graduate students.

The 9th World Congress of Cliometrics was hosted by Trinity College Dublin, July 20-22, 2023 in Dublin, Republic of Ireland.  There were 112 registered participants, as well as several graduate students of the host institution who attended.  The participants were from every continent except Antarctica.  The project supported 30 graduate student presenters.  There were approximately 36 graduate students attending. There  were 24 women (13 of the supported graduate students), and the participants include all major ethnic groups.
